content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <rdf:RDF  xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#"  xmlns="http://purl.org/rss/1.0/"  xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"  xmlns:prism="http://prismstandard.org/namespaces/1.2/basic/">   <channel rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica">     <title>Res Medica</title>   <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica</link>            <description><p>The Res Medica is the peer-reviewed Journal of the Royal Medical Society.</p><p>We accept articles written by medical students and clinicians covering clinically relevant topics. These include original, systematic review, literature review, perspective, historical, and case report articles.\ufffd\ufffd</p><p>Since its founding in 1957, the Journal has been served by both student doctors and clinicians in the publication process and is proud to be one of the longest serving Journals run <em>by</em> and <em>for</em> both medical students and clinicians.\ufffd\ufffdOur parent Society, the Royal Medical Society, is the oldest medical society in the United Kingdom and was established by medical students in 1737. Today the Journal is run by a core of student doctor editors, an international academic advisory board, a team of senior student peer reviewers, and a team of expert clinician and academic reviewers, totalling over hundred individuals.\ufffd\ufffd</p><p>The Journal is currently indexed on the Directory of Open Access Journals, Google Scholar, and is in the process of indexing with major international databases as of 2014. Please contact the editor if you have any enquiries or ideas about potential publications.</p></description>           <dc:publisher>The Royal Medical Society</dc:publisher>         <dc:language>en-US</dc:language>      <prism:publicationName>Res Medica</prism:publicationName>               <prism:issn>0482-3206</prism:issn>         <prism:copyright><p>Authors who publish with this journal agree to the following terms:</p><p>a. Authors retain copyright and grant the journal right of first publication with the work simultaneously licensed under an Attribution 2.5 UK: Scotland license.</p><p>More information on Creative Commons here:<a href="http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/scotland/deed.en_GB">http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/scotland/deed.en_GB </a></p><p>b. Authors are able to enter into separate, additional contractual arrangements for the non-exclusive distribution of the journal's published version of the work (e.g., post it to an institutional repository or publish it in a book), with an acknowledgement of its initial publication in this journal.</p><p>c. Authors are permitted and encouraged to post their work online (e.g., in institutional repositories or on their website) prior to and during the submission process, as it can lead to productive exchanges, as well as earlier and greater citation of published work (See <a href="http://opcit.eprints.org/oacitation-biblio.html" target="_new">The Effect of Open Access</a>).</p></prism:copyright> rdf:resource="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/1123"/>          <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/1124"/>                 <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/1138"/>           </rdf:Seq>   </items>  </channel>     <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/1136">        <title>Editor's Note</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/1136</link>            <description>A note from the Editor-in-Chief</description>            <dc:creator>John J Park</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-29</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-29</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>22</prism:volume>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/817">        <title>Supraventricular tachycardia and catheter ablation: Anxiety levels and patient perceptions</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/817</link>            <description><p><strong>Aim</strong>: To investigate anxiety levels and patient perception associated with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT); investigate anxiety levels and patient perception pre- and post- radiofrequency catheter ablation (RFCA); and explore any association between anxiety and patient perception with patient age and gender.</p><p><strong>Design: </strong>Follow-up quantitative and qualitative cohort study. 141 patients in a tertiary centre in Scotland who underwent an electrophysiological study and RFCA for atrioventricular nodal re-entrant tachycardia, atrioventricular re-entrant tachycardia or atrial tachycardia between 2009 and 2012 were enrolled. 59 (41.8%) were male; mean age at follow-up was 50 years.<strong></strong></p><p><strong>Interventions: </strong>Follow-up by structured phone questionnaire; mean follow-up period was 14 months. <strong></strong></p><p><strong>Main outcome measures:</strong> Anxiety level and patient perception during index episode, and anxiety level before and after RFCA.</p><p><strong>Results: </strong>During index episode, median patient anxiety, on a scale of 0\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd10, was 8. Anxiety was not associated with gender (<em>p </em>= 0.07). Patients in the lowest and highest anxiety groups tended to be older (mean 54.5 and 44.4 years respectively) compared with those in the middle 2 groups (mean 34.1 and 35.6 years). There was an association between anxiety and age (<em>p </em>= 0.039). 45 (32.0%) participants thought they were having a heart attack or dying. Before RFCA, median anxiety level was 7. 55 (39.0%) patients were afraid of complications, 21 (14.9%) patients feared being awake during RFCA. After RFCA, median anxiety was 2.5.<strong></strong></p><p><strong>Conclusions</strong>: Anxiety is a common accompaniment to SVT that may lead to greater pre-procedural anxiety. Exploring this link may allow reduction of anxiety via better psychopharmacological intervention, education, and preprocedural counselling.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Ahmed Yasser Mohamed El-Medany</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Neil Robert Grubb</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-29</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-29</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>22</prism:volume>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/776">        <title>Sleep problems in cancer: effective psychological interventions \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd a systematic review</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/776</link>            <description><p><strong>Introduction: </strong>Sleep problems are one of the most prevalent complications cancer patients experience. These have been shown to produce harmful effects such as reduced immunity and mood disturbances. While pharmacological agents for sleep problems may be used, psychological therapies should be considered where possible.</p><p><strong>Aim</strong>: The aim of this review is to evaluate the effectiveness of different psychological interventions for sleep problems in cancer patients.</p><p><strong>Methods</strong>: A systematic review was conducted. Databases searched included PsychINFO, Embase, MEDLINE, and Web of Science for papers published during the period from January 2003 to December 2013. Combinations of the following terms were used: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdsleep disturbance\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdsleep problems\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdinsomnia\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdcognitive behavioural therapy\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdCBT\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdnon-pharmacological\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdsleep hygiene\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdpsychological intervention\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdpsychological treatment\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, and \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdcancer\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd.</p><p><strong>Results: </strong>22 papers were selected for analysis. The main finding from this systematic review was that cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) and mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) is the most promising psychological intervention for the treatment of insomnia in cancer patients. Other psychological treatments such as sleep education and multimodal programmes also demonstrate good potential for use in oncology.</p><p><strong>Conclusions: </strong>Further randomized controlled trials comparing the effectiveness of CBT and MBSR in different types of cancer are required to determine their relative benefits and costs.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Hannah Elizabeth Venables</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-29</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-29</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>22</prism:volume>   </item>    <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/813">        <title>Who needs a gut anyway?</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/813</link>            <description><p>This is an up-to-date review on Chronic Intestinal Failure (CIF) and Parenteral Nutrition (PN) as a management strategy for CIF.</p><p>CIF and long-term PN are important subjects, but are superficially covered in undergraduate curricula due to the perception that they are relatively specialist areas. PN, as well as being a form of acute nutritional support, is used as a life-sustaining measure for patients with CIF due to conditions such as bowel ischaemia and Crohn\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds disease. Currently, around 500 patients receive long-term PN in the UK and the numbers are expected to rise with the aging population<sup>1</sup>. It is a costly service, requiring a multidisciplinary team effort, along with high frequency patient-healthcare interaction.</p><p>This article aims to discuss the current evidence on the causes, management and prognosis of CIF, with a particular focus on PN as a form of nutritional management. While PN seems to improve the prognosis of patients with CIF from a medical point of view, we will also explore how it affects other aspects of a patient\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds life, such as their social life and mental health.\ufffd\ufffd</p></description>            <dc:creator>Esther Ha Gyeong Park</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Stuart J Fergusson</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Connor Johnston</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Hani Syaza Syahirah Zakaria</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jay Roe Tan</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Matthew Wood</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Xavier Kai Yang Tay</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-29</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-29</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>22</prism:volume>   </item>    <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/811">        <title>The New Dual Antiplatelet Therapy Agents And Their Role in Acute Coronary Syndrome</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/811</link>            <description><p><strong>Background: </strong>Prasugrel and ticagrelor are two novel antiplatelet agents, which have been subject to large randomized trials to compare their efficacy with clopidogrel for patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS).</p><p><strong>Aim:</strong> To conduct a systematic review of prasugrel and ticagrelor as alternative therapy to clopidogrel in patients who present with ACS undergoing PCI.</p><p><strong>Methods: </strong>The articles cited in this paper were searched on PubMed, MEDLINE, and Plymouth University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Metalib database. The search terms used included \ufffd\ufffd\ufffddual antiplatelet therapy\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdprasugrel\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdticagrelor\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, and \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdclopidogrel resistance\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. <strong></strong></p><p><strong>Discussion: </strong>The main indications for the use of prasugrel based on current understanding are patients presenting with acute STEMI referred for primary PCI, ACS patients with DM, or those who have a high risk of stent thrombosis. Ticagrelor, on the other hand, may provide optimal benefit for patients with NSTEMI treated with conservative or invasive therapy, those with previous TIA or stroke, advanced age, or small body surface. <strong></strong></p><p><strong>Conclusion: </strong>Prasugrel and ticagrelor have been shown to be adequate P2Y<sub>12</sub> antiplatelet therapy alternatives to clopidogrel in the management of patients with ACS. While prasugrel and ticagrelor have both been shown to clinically improve platelet inhibition and significantly reduce the incidence of stent thrombosis compared with clopidogrel therapy, both increase the risk of a significant bleeding incident. Both ticagrelor and prasugrel have been shown to be appropriate and effective treatment alternatives for ACS patients who display clopidogrel treatment resistance or failure.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Gareth John Williams</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-29</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-29</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>22</prism:volume>   </item>    <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/763">        <title>A review on the use of aspirin as a form of chemoprevention to reduce colorectal cancer</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/763</link>            <description><p><strong>Background: </strong>Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the second most common cancer worldwide. Estimated lifetime risk of CRC is 5%, with an incidence of 1 million new cases and 600\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd000 deaths worldwideevery year. Lifestyle, dietary, and genetic factors play a crucial part in the development of colorectal cancer. Chemoprevention is a method of CRC prevention.</p><p><strong>Aim</strong>: This review aims to identify the effectiveness of aspirin in preventing CRC in high-, moderate- and low-risk patients.</p><p><strong>Method</strong>: Electronic databases were used to search for randomized controlled trials (RCTs) from 1989 to 2012 in MEDLINE, EMBASE, CINAHL, the Cochrane Database of Systemic Reviews, and Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials. The search terms employed were \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdhereditary colorectal cancer\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdLynch syndrome\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdcolorectal cancer\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdaspirin\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, and \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdcolorectal cancer\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd.</p><p><strong>Results</strong>: Aspirin reduces the incidence and recurrence of adenoma in patients with high to moderate risk of developing CRC.</p><p><strong>Conclusion</strong>: There is evidence which supports the use of aspirin in reducing the risk of colorectal cancer in genetically predisposed patients and moderate-risk groups. Higher doses of aspirin appear to reduce the incidence of CRC.<strong> </strong>It is unclear what the optimum dose to start is, and the duration of administration that will provide effective chemoprevention. Further research is needed to answer these questions.<strong></strong></p></description>            <dc:creator>Sadiq Shanaz</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-29</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-29</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>22</prism:volume>   </item>    <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/743">        <title>An Estimate of Lyme Borreliosis Incidence in Western Europe</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/743</link>            <description><p>Background: Lyme borreliosis (LB) is the most common zoonotic disease transmitted by ticks in the USA and Europe. This review aims to estimate the regional burden of LB in Western Europe. Data from previous publications were used to calculate the mean incidence. The mean incidence rates were then combined to estimate the regional burden and a population-weighted regional burden of disease based on the standardized incidence from the included studies and the total population at risk.</p><p>Methods: Reviews and surveillance reports identified by the initial database search were first assessed for eligibility by their title and abstract, and subsequently by a more detailed review of the source for the most recent data regarding LB. 11 sources of incidence data were included in the review, representing 17 countries in total. Incidence estimates were calculated from reported values and population data.</p><p>Results: Countries in Western Europe have a large variance in the incidence rates. The highest reported incidences for LB were reported in southern Sweden with 464 per 100\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd000 and the lowest in Italy of 0.001 per 100\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd000. The unweighted mean for the included data provided an incidence of 56.3 per 100\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd000 persons per year, equating to approximately 232\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd125 cases in one year throughout the region. The calculated population-weighted average incidence for the regional burden of LB in Western Europe was 22.05 cases per 100\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd000 person-years.</p><p>Conclusions: LB is an emerging disease and the most common zoonotic infection in Western Europe approaching endemic proportions in many European countries. The population-weighted incidence has been estimated by this study to be 22.04 per 100\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd000 person-years. Concordant and well-conducted surveillance and disease awareness should continue to be encouraged to monitor LB as tick numbers and activity increases.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Robert Alexander Sykes</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-29</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-29</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>22</prism:volume>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/732">        <title>Interstitial Lung Disease in Rheumatoid Arthritis: A Clinical Dilemma</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/732</link>            <description><p>Rheumatoid arthritis (RA)\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdassociated interstitial lung disease (RA-ILD) is an increasingly common extra-articular cause of mortality and morbidity in RA. Here, we present the case of an 82-year-old female suffering from RA-ILD. She presented with a 20-year history of RA with new-onset progressively worsening dyspnoea, pyrexia, and dry cough, which were not responsive to initial antibiotics. Moreover, she had been on long-term methotrexate, which can cause pulmonary disease. Investigations revealed raised inflammatory markers, restrictive lung patterns, and radiological features of ILD. She was treated with a tapering course of oral prednisolone and home oxygen, which provided some symptomatic improvement. Diagnosis of RA-ILD can be challenging due to several contributing factors.\ufffd\ufffd Optimal treatment is controversial, and corticosteroids have been widely used but with limited effects. There is evidence directed at potential therapeutic benefit from a number of newer agents, which are discussed.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd</p></description>            <dc:creator>Timothy Shao Ern Tan</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-29</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-29</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>22</prism:volume>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/822">        <title>The Management of Gout in Primary Care - Are We Doing it Right?</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/822</link>            <description><p><strong><span>Introduction: </span></strong><span>The soaring incidence of gout in the United Kingdom suggests that medical practitioners should be increasingly aware of optimizing management of gout, which is aimed at pain relief, preservation of joint function and preventing recurrent attacks. Recent guidelines published by the British Society of Rheumatology (BSR), have provided clinicians with a framework for achieving these aims. </span></p><p><strong><span>Aims</span></strong><span>: To evaluate the management of gout in a primary care centre in North West England against recognized standards. </span></p><p><strong><span>Methods</span></strong><span>:\ufffd\ufffdAn electronic search on EMIS Web using the Read codes \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdgout\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdgouty arthritis\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, with a specified period of 2010\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd2013, generated a cohort of patients who were categorized into 2 groups: those prescribed urate-lowering therapy (allopurinol) and those not. Patients on febuxostat were excluded. Clinical data from the patients were extracted and retrospectively audited. </span></p><p><strong><span>Results</span></strong><span>: A total of 112 patients were identified, of which only 46% (<em>n</em> = 52) of patients were reviewed after an acute attack. Among those who were prescribed allopurinol, only 19% (<em>n </em>= 12) achieved target serum urate levels while only 67% (<em>n</em> = 42) had their serum urate levels checked regularly and 31% (<em>n</em> = 20) had dosage adjustments. Comparatively, in patients not prescribed allopurinol, a few indications for initiating allopurinol were detected: 29% (<em>n</em> = 12) had more than one attack of gout in a year, 27% (<em>n</em> = 11) suffered from renal insufficiency, 2% (<em>n</em> = 1) presented with tophi, and 17% (<em>n</em> = 7) were on diuretics.</span></p><p><strong><span>Conclusion</span></strong><span>: Gout management in this primary care centre is not fully concordant to the BSR guidelines. Clearly, there is a need to improve adherence, particularly in the tight monitoring of serum uric acid levels, medications review, appropriate use of allopurinol, where indicated, and patient follow-up.</span></p></description>            <dc:creator>Evelyn Li Ping Lim</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Timothy Shao Ern Tan</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-29</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-29</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>22</prism:volume>   </item>    <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/808">        <title>An Audit of the Management of ABPA in CF patients at Alder Hey Children\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Hospital</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/808</link>            <description><div class="WordSection1"><p><strong>Background</strong>: Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) is a persistent problem for many cystic fibrosis (CF) patients. It is a challenging condition to diagnose and manage.</p><p><strong>Aim:</strong> The CF team at Alder Hey Children\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Hospital aimed to assess how consistently and effectively they were managing the condition. A diagnosis and management monitoring tool was used to systematically draw data for auditing.</p><p><strong>Methods</strong>: Out of 87 patients under the care of the CF team, 20 had previously been diagnosed with ABPA. 60% had 4 out of the 4 minimal diagnostic criteria. 75% grew cultures positive for <em>A. fumigatus </em>at some point since their diagnosis of ABPA. All patients had received prednisolone therapy at some point since diagnosis, with 7 patients receiving the maximum starting dose of 40\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdmg and 1.29\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdmg/kg for those below maximum dose. 14 patients were prescribed antifungal therapy. 5 patients had levels ordered when they started the therapy, 5 had levels ordered between 45 and 1149 days after prescription, and 3 have had no levels ordered to date. A second audit was performed one year later to complete the audit cycle.</p></div><p><strong>Results</strong>: This cohort of patients had a much higher prevalence of ABPA than the general CF population.</p><div class="WordSection2"><p><strong>Discussion</strong>: Research into the relationship between ABPA exacerbation and concurrent infections or antibiotic therapy could help identify risk factors for developing an exacerbation. There should be discussions about how to improve the consistency in initial dosing of prednisolone, considering guidelines.</p><p><strong>Conclusion</strong>: There should be more itraconazole levels taken to ensure safety and effectiveness of antifungal therapy.</p></div><p><strong><br clear="all" /></strong></p></description>            <dc:creator>Hannah Elizabeth Beresford</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Eleanor Hunter</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-29</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-29</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>22</prism:volume>   </item>    <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/812">        <title>Audit into the Appropriateness of CT Cervical Spine Scan Requesting in the Emergency Department</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/812</link>            <description><p><strong>Introduction</strong>:\ufffd\ufffd The use of computed tomography (CT) imaging of the cervical spine (CS) is now the recommended primary screening modality for suspected CS injuries following trauma. The aim of this audit is to review the appropriate use of CS CT imaging in the emergency department (ED) and assess compliance with the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) head injury clinical guidelines.</p><p><strong>Methods</strong>: Charts were reviewed for the last 50 trauma patients to receive a CS CT scan following a request from the ED at University Hospital Limerick between 10 July 2013 and 19 December 2013. The NICE clinical guideline 176 on head injury was used as the standard of care. These data were used to perform a retrospective audit to assess patients who satisfied NICE criteria to qualify for a CS CT scan.</p><p><strong>Results</strong>: 45 patients who had undergone a CS CT scan were identified, this group had a mean age of 42 years and 71% of them were male. At least one of the NICE guideline criteria was fulfilled in 100% of patients who had a CS CT, with 2.64 of the criteria fulfilled on average. Plain-film X-ray radiography (PF) was inadequate for diagnosis in 20 (44.4%) patients.</p><p><strong>Discussion</strong>: ED consultants appropriately refer patients for CS CT scans following CS trauma and adhere to NICE head injury clinical guidelines.</p><p><strong>Conclusion</strong>: Having guidelines in place in the ED and adopting CS CT imaging as an initial screening modality following CS injury may reduce time to definitive care and improve resource implications.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Marc Adam Jacobson</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Damien Ryan</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-29</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-29</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>22</prism:volume>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/746">        <title>Schizophrenia - From Devilry to Disease</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/746</link>            <description><p>Symptoms of psychotic diseases historically instilled fear and distrust in onlookers, who associated them with witchcraft, demonic spirits, and the devil. From Egyptian medicine to medieval witch hunts, psychotic diseases have been associated with the supernatural throughout history. Yet even with advancements in neuroscience and improvements in our understanding of mental illness, stigma surrounding mental health remains prevalent today. Schizophrenia is a psychiatric illness which has evaded a clinical definition until relatively recently; even now, the precise features that constitute a schizophrenic patient are open to dispute. This article explores the ancient history of mental health with a particular emphasis on psychosis, and also considers the changing attitudes and understanding of schizophrenia throughout the last century, leading to its clinical definition as a treatable condition.<strong></strong></p></description>            <dc:creator>Ruaridh Owen</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-29</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-29</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>22</prism:volume>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/1122">        <title>Why should medical students be concerned about global governance?</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/1122</link>            <description><p>This article introduces the work of the Lancet-University of Oslo Commission on Global<br />Governance for Health and its parallel Youth Commission, which published their reports in<br />2014. Because the role of socioeconomic conditions in the production of health outcomes and\ufffd\ufffdhealth inequities has already long been recognized, the Commission further examined the\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdpolitical determinants of health,\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd particularly the systemic dysfunctions of global governance,\ufffd\ufffdespecially in areas that are deemed as \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdnon-health\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd such as trade, finance, agriculture, migration,\ufffd\ufffdand security. To support the Commission\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds thesis, the Youth Commission then proposed the\ufffd\ufffdadoption of the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdcapability approach\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd as a guiding framework of global governance for health.\ufffd\ufffdFirst introduced by Amartya Sen, this approach emphasizes on the need for equality in the space\ufffd\ufffdof capabilities or freedoms needed to achieve various things that people value. Nevertheless,\ufffd\ufffdwhile the road toward better global governance remains elusive, the next generation of leaders,\ufffd\ufffdincluding medical students, can already be prepared to tackle these seemingly insurmountable\ufffd\ufffdchallenges. Various ways by which medical students can learn and understand global governance\ufffd\ufffdand global health include incorporation into the medical curriculum, internships, and\ufffd\ufffdinvolvement in student organizations with global health orientation. Such modalities are hoped\ufffd\ufffdto contribute towards the full reorientation of the health professions to consider, address, and\ufffd\ufffdreach out to other sectors that govern the broader, underlying social determinants of health.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Renzo Guinto</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-29</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-29</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>22</prism:volume>   </item>    <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/1123">        <title>Transforming and Scaling Up Health Professional Education</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/1123</link>            <description><p>The Human Resources for Health (HRH) agenda transcends national borders. In particular,\ufffd\ufffdeducation and training for health professionals around the globe is faced with new\ufffd\ufffdepidemiological and demographic challenges, as well as the impact of climate change. Looking\ufffd\ufffdbeyond the existing models and systems for health professional education, the World Health Organization is leading an effort aimed at increasing the quantity but also the quality, relevance, and sustainability of the health workforce. Evidenced-based policy guidelines, along with political commitment to the goal of universal health coverage, bring countries closer towards sustainable and equitable access to health services.</p><p>It is imperative that the new generation of health professionals must be capable of participating in and implementing reforms of health professional education within the broader global HRH strategy and post-2015 development agenda.</p><p>\ufffd\ufffd</p></description>            <dc:creator>Erica Wheeler</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Julian Fisher</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Sam Wing-Sum Li</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-29</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-29</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>22</prism:volume>   </item>    <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/1124">        <title>A Long-Term, Sustainable, Inclusive, International Model for Facilitating Junior Doctors and Medical Student\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdled Publishing</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/1124</link>            <description><p>Medical student textbooks are traditionally written by senior clinicians, with little if any input\ufffd\ufffdfrom medical students or junior doctors (\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdjuniors\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd). However, juniors have been shown to be\ufffd\ufffdeffective educators in various teaching settings. They have a good appreciation of the learning\ufffd\ufffdneeds and styles of contemporary students. We hypothesized such benefits of junior-led teaching\ufffd\ufffdcould be successfully applied to medical textbooks.\ufffd\ufffd</p><p>This article describes the Unofficial Guide to Medicine project, a novel, junior-led approach to\ufffd\ufffdtextbook writing. We discuss the process from the recruitment of juniors through to the final\ufffd\ufffdpublication of a textbook, comparing and contrasting our approach with more traditional\ufffd\ufffdpublishing models. The specific roles juniors perform and their potential progression from junior\ufffd\ufffdreviewer to editor is explained, as is the collaboration with senior clinicians. Juniors not only lead\ufffd\ufffdthe process of writing, but also editing, graphic design, and print review. The use of social media\ufffd\ufffdto gain feedback from a large cohort of juniors during the book writing process and the positive\ufffd\ufffdeffects this has on the development of titles is highlighted, as are the potential difficulties this\ufffd\ufffddynamic writing model produces.</p><p><br />We finish by looking at feedback from the published titles from the series, discussing the<br />benefits to those juniors who participate and describe how you can get involved.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Zeshan Qureshi</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-29</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-29</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>22</prism:volume>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/1138">        <title>Credits</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/resmedica/article/view/1138</link>            <description>Credits.</description>            <dc:creator>James Waddell</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-29</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-29</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>22</prism:volume>   </item>  </rdf:RDF>
